channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [LOG4J2-1419] Memory leak on Tomcat shutdown
item.description:
Running log4j2 v2.6 with disruptor 3.3.4. AsyncLoggers configured (-DLog4jContextSelector=org.apache.logging.log4j.core.async.AsyncLoggerContextSelector), log4j-web also included. Web application deployed in Tomcat 7.0.69 with configured servlet 3.0. catalina.properties does not include the log4j*.jar entry.

Server log:

As you can see in line with timestamp 2016-06-08 00:18:23,260 LoggerContext was stopped. Next step what Log4j2 doing is initialize new LoggerContext (2016-06-08 00:18:23,294) and when it done (2016-06-08 00:18:23,367) we have memory leak...

My log4j2.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<Configuration status="TRACE" monitorInterval="60">
    <Appenders>
        <Console name="Console" target="SYSTEM_OUT">
            <PatternLayout pattern="%d [%-5p] [%c]: %m%n" />
        </Console>

        <RollingRandomAccessFile name="AppLog"
                fileName="${sys:catalina.base}/logs/test.log"
                immediateFlush="true"
                filePattern="${sys:catalina.base}/logs/logs/test-%d{yyyy-MM-dd_HHmmss-SSS}.log.gz">
            <PatternLayout pattern="[%d{dd/MM/yy HH:mm:ss:sss}] [%-5p] [%c]: %m%n" />
            <Policies>
                <SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy size="250 MB" />
            </Policies>
        </RollingRandomAccessFile>

        <RollingRandomAccessFile name="HibernateLog"
                                 fileName="${sys:catalina.base}/logs/test-hibernate.log"
                                 immediateFlush="true"
                                 filePattern="${sys:catalina.base}/logs/logs/test-hibernate-%d{yyyy-MM-dd_HHmmss-SSS}.log.gz">
            <PatternLayout pattern="[%d{dd/MM/yy HH:mm:ss:sss}] [%-5p] [%c]: %m%n" />
            <Policies>
                <SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy size="250 MB" />
            </Policies>
        </RollingRandomAccessFile>
    </Appenders>
    <Loggers>
        <Logger name="org.simple.logging" level="DEBUG" additivity="false">
            <AppenderRef ref="AppLog"/>
        </Logger>

        <Logger name="org.springframework" level="INFO" additivity="false">
            <AppenderRef ref="AppLog"/>
        </Logger>

        <Logger name="org.hibernate" level="INFO" additivity="false">
            <AppenderRef ref="HibernateLog"/>
            <AppenderRef ref="AppLog"/>
        </Logger>

        <Root level="DEBUG">
            <AppenderRef ref="Console" />
            <AppenderRef ref="AppLog"/>
        </Root>
    </Loggers>
</Configuration>

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
Interesting. It looks like the new context is started at 2016-06-08 00:18:23,278.
Anyone any idea what could trigger a new context to be started after the first one is stopped?

vasiapupkin I've tried to trace it down in the code but got stuck. I suspect there is a call to LogManager.getLogger() that happens somewhere after the application has been stopped. I need to add debug logging to show a stack trace when the LoggerContext is started. If I add this, will you be able to build from git master and try to reproduce the issue?

I committed code to master that will print a stack trace at DEBUG level in the status logger if system property log4j.LoggerContext.trace.start is set to true.

Can you try to reproduce the issue with this and show the stack trace?
After feedback from the Log4j community I changed the system property name to log4j.LoggerContext.stacktrace.on.start.

Below you can find log for code from master branch and setted log4j.LoggerContext.stacktrace.on.start = true:

Problem is in initialization order contexts.
Spring context (ContextLoaderListener) starts before log4j (Log4jServletContextListener). Therefore spring context closed after log4j, which invoking method cleanupAttributes in ContextCleanupListener.class with logger.
If I manually init Log4jServletContextListener before ContextLoaderListener in my web.xml all working fine (Log4jServletContextListener shutting down after ContextLoaderListener):

    <context-param>
        <param-name>isLog4jAutoInitializationDisabled</param-name>
        <param-value>true</param-value>
    </context-param>
    <listener>
        <listener-class>org.apache.logging.log4j.web.Log4jServletContextListener</listener-class>
    </listener>
    <filter>
        <filter-name>log4jServletFilter</filter-name>
        <filter-class>org.apache.logging.log4j.web.Log4jServletFilter</filter-class>
    </filter>
    <filter-mapping>
        <filter-name>log4jServletFilter</filter-name>
        <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern>
        <dispatcher>REQUEST</dispatcher>
        <dispatcher>FORWARD</dispatcher>
        <dispatcher>INCLUDE</dispatcher>
        <dispatcher>ERROR</dispatcher>
        <dispatcher>ASYNC</dispatcher><!-- Servlet 3.0 w/ disabled auto-initialization only; not supported in 2.5 -->
    </filter-mapping>

    <context-param>
        <param-name>contextConfigLocation</param-name>
        <param-value>WEB-INF/spring/spring-webs.xml</param-value>
    </context-param>
    <listener>
        <listener-class>org.springframework.web.context.ContextLoaderListener</listener-class>
    </listener>

In documentation (https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/manual/webapp.html) I found something like this:

Once you disable auto-initialization, you must initialize Log4j as you would a Servlet 2.5 web application. You must do so in a way that this initialization happens before any other application code (such as Spring Framework startup code) executes.

Do I always must manually setting initialization order contexts in app with spring?

Actually I don't know.

Web-app experts on the mailing list: Is Log4j auto-initialization supposed to ensure the Log4j context starts before the Spring context?
Can you test your use case with the latest from Git master?

noticed the same problem and workaround (as described by vasiapupkin]) with Log4j2 v2.9.1 on tomcat v7.0.82

It seems like the

  • Log4jServletContainerInitializer.onStartUp() did get called first and executed.

then the Spring ContextLoaderListener as configured in web.xml will get created, then somehow the

  • Spring ContextLoaderListener.contextInitialized will get call first
  • then Log4jServletContextListener.contextInitialized

yeah, just tested with v2.10.0, same

  • SEVERE: The web application [/TestLog4j] appears to have started a thread named [Log4j2-TF-8-Scheduled-2] but has failed to stop it. This is very likely to create a memory leak.

The problem seems to be related to having the following settings in the web.xml.

    <context-param>
        <param-name>contextConfigLocation</param-name>
        <param-value>...l</param-value>
    </context-param>
    <listener>
        <listener-class>org.springframework.web.context.ContextLoaderListener</listener-class>
    </listener>

technically, might not need those settings as Spring (tested with v4.3.11) comes with its:

  • SpringServletContainerInitializer (and/or SpringWebApplicationInitializer)

Removing the settings from web.xml seems able to avoid the problem, but still not sure why having those settings in the web.xml causes the issue.

if Spring ContextLoaderListener is included in web.xml,

<listener-class>org.springframework.web.context.ContextLoaderListener</listener-class>

the issue might be because of; from servlet spec 3.0, section 8.2.3:

4. The web.xml of the web application has the highest precedence when resolving
conflicts between the web.xml, web-fragment.xml and annotations.
I know it's been a while on this, but it might be the same root cause as what I posted over in response to LOG4J2-1606.
